prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: What the he'll is going on that we are struggling with these facilities that take care of the mentally challenged or health care for Alzheimer's patients that have other medical issues?  St. Mary's in Grand Junction just discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's without rehab for the hip and no place with beds open for Alzheimer's!  Ludicrous!  The "authorities" closed the facility to accommodate "challenged " residents here last year and re-located them to Denver.  Again, ridiculous!  Our health care system is without compassion and based on the bottom line!  The worst part is drug addicts, emergency room mangers of all sorts can get care but we treat those who have health issues as seniors like shit! Sad state of affairs!  Shame on healthcare and those who do not fight for dignity in end of life care!  Shameful!  Politicians should be shamed for not supporting a bill that cares for these people!
stories: How frustrating that healthcare facilities for mentally challenged individuals and patients with Alzheimer's requiring further medical treatment are falling short, resulting in inadequate care and discharge without rehabilitation or subsequent facility placement. For example, St. Mary's hospital in Grand Junction recently discharged a friend who broke a hip and has Alzheimer's without rehabilitation and failed to find an open bed at an Alzheimer's care facility. This situation seems incomprehensible. Authorities relocated facilities to accommodate residents from one area to another, causing further inconvenience. Unfortunately, our healthcare system prioritizes profit over compassion, neglecting the wellbeing of vulnerable populations. Moreover, individuals battling addiction and requiring emergency treatment receive readily available care, while those needing prolonged health services are undervalued and ignored. This tragic state is deserving of widespread shame and outcry. Healthcare providers and political leaders must take proactive measures to ensure dignified care for the most needy among us, especially during their final days.

It is disheartening to note that healthcare facilities catering to mentally challenged individuals and patients with Alzheimer's, requiring ongoing medical care, are frequently in short supply, leading to inadequate treatment and untimely discharge without rehabilitation or suitable facility placement. One striking example is a local hospital's failure to provide rehabilitation to a friend with Alzheimer's following a hip fracture, as well as its inability to find available beds at a care facility specializing in Alzheimer's care. This situation seems utterly bewildering. Unfortunately, in order to optimize revenue, our healthcare system tends to favor profits over compassion, which disadvantages vulnerable populations. Moreover, patients struggling with addiction typically have access to swift emergency treatment, while those in need of prolonged healthcare services are often underrated and ignored. This deplorable state is grossly deserving of loud protests and national outrage. Healthcare professionals and government leaders must promptly address the dearth of dignified care for the most needy among us, particularly at their time of greatest vulnerability.

It's alarming that healthcare facilities caring for the mentally impaired and Alzheimer's patients, who require consistent medical care, are repeatedly in short supply, leading to subpar treatment and premature discharges without adequate care or placement. A stark example is a local hospital neglecting rehabilitation for a friend with Alzheimer's after a hip fracture, and being unable to find suitable beds at an Alzheimer's-care facility. This injustice is mystifying. Unfortunately, our healthcare system prioritizes profit over compassion, disadvantages marginalized groups, and neglects chronic patients in favor of acute care. While addiction patients receive swift treatment, those in prolonged need often suffer in silence. This unacceptable situation demands widespread protest and national concern. Healthcare providers and leaders must urgently rectify the lack of dignified care for our most vulnerable members, particularly in times of greatest need.

The dearth of healthcare facilities catering to individuals with mental disabilities and Alzheimer's, who depend on continuous medical care, has resulted in reduced treatment quality and premature discharges without proper care or accommodations. I find myself aghast at the reality of a hospital neglecting a friend's rehabilitation following a hip fracture and failing to secure fitting beds at an Alzheimer's-care facility. This unjust situation is particularly perplexing. Our healthcare system appears to place profit above empathy, favors those who require immediate treatment over those enduring chronic conditions, and neglects the most vulnerable members of our society, like the marginalized and chronically ill. While swift care is available for addiction cases, those in dire need often go unnoticed. This distressing scenario demands widespread condemnation and national attention. Healthcare professionals and leaders must rectify the shortage of dignified care for our most defenseless populations immediately, particularly in moments of greatest need.

The dearth of accessible healthcare facilities for individuals with mental disabilities and Alzheimer's has led to reduced treatment quality and premature discharges, highlighting the grave need for suitable care and accommodations. I am outraged by reports of a hospital neglecting rehabilitation care after a hip fracture and failing to secure suitable accommodation at an Alzheimer's-care facility. This distressing situation raises fundamental concerns. Our healthcare system appears to prioritize profit over compassion, giving preferential treatment to those with immediate needs over those with chronic conditions, leaving vulnerable populations like the marginalized and ill-neglected. Meanwhile, those with severe chronic illness often go overlooked, as instant attention is readily available for addiction cases. The egregious failure to provide dignified care for our most vulnerable citizens is unconscionable and demands immediate action and nationwide attention.
